description:
Aquamicrobium segne is a species of bacteria that belongs to the family Cytophagaceae within the phylum Bacteroidetes. It is a Gram-negative, strictly aerobic, and non-spore-forming microorganism.

Aquamicrobium segne is characterized by its slow growth and a rod-shaped cellular morphology. It is found in aquatic environments, particularly in freshwater and brackish water habitats. The species is known to be psychrotolerant, meaning it can grow at low temperatures, typically ranging from 4°C to 30°C.

Physiologically, Aquamicrobium segne is able to utilize a variety of organic compounds as carbon and energy sources, including carbohydrates, amino acids, and organic acids. It is also capable of degrading complex polymeric substances, such as cellulose and chitin.

The genome of Aquamicrobium segne has been sequenced, providing insights into its metabolic capabilities and ecological adaptations. This information contributes to our understanding of the role of this bacterium in aquatic ecosystems and its potential applications in biotechnology or environmental remediation.
